700346f-a.text:
West 230th Street, east from Kingsbridge Ave., to Broadway, showing the Macomb Mansion, adjoining the N.W. corner of the latter thoroughfare, In 1693 the house was known as "the public house at the north end of the bridge", and in 1776 as Cox 's Tavern. Alexander Macomb bought the house in 1779 and it was sold in 1848 to J.H. Godwin, and is often referred to as the Godwin Mansion. Spuyten Duyvil Creek is shown in the foreground. It is now (1938) filled in and the Kingsbridge freight yard of the New
York Central Railroad is situated there.
1906.
Brown Brothers.

701378f-a.text:
Kingsbridge Ave., west side, between West 23Oth and West 231st Streets,
showing St. John's Church (R.C.).
October 27, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

701383f-a.text:
(1)
Kingsbridge Ave., north from Marble Hill Ave., across West 231st Street, showing (left) at the N.W. corner of the latter street, 2-story building of the New York Telephone Company. Kingsbridge Avenue, at the point of vantage, is the dividing line between the Bronx and the Marble Hill section of New York County (Manhattan).
October 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Part of the same. An exclusive view of the west side of the avenue at West 230th Street. The Telephone Company branch building is prominently shown.
October 26, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
